what the policy of the paper under its current editors has been,
and what it will continue to be.
The aim and policy of the News-Letter's news coverage is the
same as that of any reputable paper: to cover happenings in its
community in an honest and unbiased manner, giving the truth
without distortions unnecessarily injurious to its community.
We work to publish the news. We accept with one reservation
the definition of news given above. It is admittedly vague, for news
varies with readership for any paper or magazine. The reservation
we place on the definition is simple: As a publication of a nonprofit educational institution we are obligated to avoid coverage
which will unnecessarily injure the reputation of the university
or seriously hamper its educational processes.
The words "unnecessarily injure" need further discussion.
The way we can injure the university is by publishing accounts of
university activities which have hitherto been kept out of the
public eye because they were considered to be unrepresentative
bad publicity. Certain items, if dramatically treated, assume a

or news service in the country.
The News-Letter, however, is obligated only to avoid distorting
the news by emphasis or fabrication. It is not obligated to cover
